title: Understand valuation basics
content: Startup valuation is about estimating how much a startup is worth today, usually before it generates consistent revenue. Instead of profit, early valuations are driven by potential—factors like idea strength, market size, team quality, and projected growth.

title: Factor in startup stage
content: The valuation approach changes depending on the startup’s stage. Early-stage startups (idea or MVP phase) are typically valued using qualitative methods like the Berkus or Scorecard Method. Later-stage startups with revenues use financial metrics like revenue multiples or DCF.

title: Check market & traction
content: Investors examine how big the market is (TAM) and how fast you’re gaining traction. Metrics like user growth, recurring revenue, partnerships, and conversion rates help validate your product-market fit and future potential.

title: Analyze key metrics
content: Important financial metrics include CAC (Customer Acquisition Cost), LTV (Lifetime Value), Burn Rate, and Runway. A healthy LTV:CAC ratio (3:1 or better), along with low burn and a long runway, indicates a strong and sustainable business model.

title: Team, product, IP strength
content: A strong founding team with relevant experience, a well-built product, and any intellectual property (like patents or proprietary tech) can significantly increase valuation. Investors often invest in the team’s ability to execute, not just the idea.

title: Ownership & dilution
content: Startup equity is a delicate balance. Founders want control; investors want a fair stake. Understanding your cap table, how future funding rounds dilute shares, and using instruments like SAFEs or convertible notes helps align incentives and preserve ownership.
